document_title: Validation of Methods to Assess the Immunoglobulin Gene Repertoire in Tissues Obtained from Mice on the International Space Station
summary_full: This study aimed to validate methods for assessing the immunoglobulin (Ig) gene repertoire in mouse tissues, particularly for samples collected under the constraints of spaceflight on the International Space Station (ISS). The researchers compared different sample preparation (whole tissue vs. single-cell suspension) and sequencing techniques (Illumina MiSeq and HiSeq) to ensure that these methods do not introduce bias into the antibody repertoire characterization. They developed and validated a bioinformatics workflow for analyzing Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) data, focusing on IgH and IgÎº variable gene usage, junctional regions, and modifications. The study found that whole tissue preparations, when combined with size selection, yield a high number of antibody sequences and comparable results to traditional single-cell suspensions. The developed workflow, which uses multiple mapping techniques and sequence selection, was validated against existing murine antibody repertoire studies and is suitable for future spaceflight experiments.
key_findings: Whole tissue preparations from mouse spleens are suitable for assessing the immunoglobulin gene repertoire, yielding comparable results to single-cell suspensions.
Size selection of RNA fragments (275-800 nt) enhances the number of identified antibody sequences, including productive ones.
A validated bioinformatics workflow using multiple mapping strategies can accurately characterize Ig gene usage (V, D, J, and constant regions) and CDR3 composition without primer bias.
Both MiSeq and HiSeq sequencing platforms can be used, but longer reads (achieved through paired-end sequencing and merging) are preferable for comprehensive repertoire analysis.
Genome mapping of sequencing reads provides a more consistent correlation with established methods compared to reference mapping for short reads (HiSeq).
future_research_fields: Investigating the impact of spaceflight on the antibody repertoire in more detail.
Studying the immune response to vaccination in spaceflight conditions.
Applying the validated NGS and bioinformatics workflow to other biological questions and sample types.
Further optimization of sample collection and storage methods for spaceflight experiments.

conclusions: The study successfully validated methods for assessing the immunoglobulin gene repertoire in mouse tissues, demonstrating that whole tissue preparations and size selection are effective for spaceflight samples. A robust bioinformatics workflow was developed and validated, enabling accurate characterization of antibody repertoires without primer bias, thus laying the groundwork for future immunological studies in space.
impact_statement: This research establishes reliable methods for analyzing immune system diversity in spaceflight, crucial for understanding astronaut health and developing countermeasures.
